articles.headline: Trump Visits Afghanistan and Says He Reopened Talks With Taliban
articles.snippet: Details were unclear. The declaration came on an unannounced trip as the president seeks to highlight a record of achievement while he campaigns for re-election.
articles.abstract: Details were unclear. The declaration came on an unannounced trip as the president seeks to highlight a record of achievement while he campaigns for re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGRAM AIR FIELD, Afghanistan — President Trump paid an unannounced Thanksgiving visit to American troops in Afghanistan on Thursday and declared that he had reopened peace negotiations with the Taliban less than three months after scuttling talks in hopes of ending 18 years of war.

articles.headline: Meet the Man Loosening Bank Regulation, One Detail at a Time
articles.snippet: Some say Randal Quarles is giving big banks a gift, little by little. Others call it needed fine-tuning. He pledges allegiance to efficiency.
articles.abstract: Some say Randal Quarles is giving big banks a gift, little by little. Others call it needed fine-tuning. He pledges allegiance to efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first 21 months on the job, Randal K. Quarles, the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman for supervision and regulation, met at least 22 times with partners at his former law firm, Davis Polk & Wardwell, which represents many of the nation’s largest banks.

articles.headline: The 72-Hour War Over Christmas
articles.snippet: The mayor of Charleston, W.Va., wanted her city to be more welcoming to all faiths and people, so she changed an annual celebration to the ‘Winter Parade.’ It didn’t last long.
articles.abstract: The mayor of Charleston, W.Va., wanted her city to be more welcoming to all faiths and people, so she changed an annual celebration to the ‘Winter Parade.’ It didn’t last long.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The first shot was fired in the middle of the afternoon in early October, back when the Appalachian leaves had barely turned orange and store shelves were lined with Halloween candy.

articles.headline: Warren Wealth Tax Has Wide Support, Except Among One Group
articles.snippet: Most college-educated Republican men oppose the plan, which otherwise finds wide backing. On Medicare for all, divisions are more starkly partisan.
articles.abstract: Most college-educated Republican men oppose the plan, which otherwise finds wide backing. On Medicare for all, divisions are more starkly partisan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s plan to tax the assets of America’s wealthiest individuals continues to draw broad support from voters, across party, gender and educational lines. Only one slice of the electorate opposes it staunchly: Republican men with college degrees.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: How Kamala Harris’s Campaign Unraveled
articles.snippet: Ms. Harris is the only 2020 Democrat who has fallen hard out of the top tier of candidates. She has proved to be an uneven campaigner who changes her message and tactics to little effect and has a staff torn into factions.
articles.abstract: Ms. Harris is the only 2020 Democrat who has fallen hard out of the top tier of candidates. She has proved to be an uneven campaigner who changes her message and tactics to little effect and has a staff torn into factions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early November, a few days after Senator Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign announced widespread layoffs and an intensified focus on Iowa, her senior aides gathered for a staff meeting at their Baltimore headquarters and pelted the campaign manager, Juan Rodriguez, with questions.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Astead W. Herndon and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Iraq Prime Minister Says He Will Resign Amid Protests
articles.snippet: The announcement comes after demonstrators set fire to the Iranian Consulate and hundreds died in antigovernment unrest.
articles.abstract: The announcement comes after demonstrators set fire to the Iranian Consulate and hundreds died in antigovernment unrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Pressured by an expanding protest movement and a rising death toll, Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi of Iraq said Friday that he would submit his resignation to Parliament, taking the country into greater uncertainty and possibly months of turmoil ahead.
